metadata.product: COWIN E7 Active Noise Cancelling Headphones Bluetooth Headphones

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Good morning, Benjamin. Thanks so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Mike, and I’m a customer insights specialist with COWIN. We really value feedback from our customers, and we saw your review of the E7 headphones, so we wanted to reach out and learn a bit more about your experience.

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, no problem, Mike. Glad to help. I mean, I put a lot of thought into that review, so hopefully, it's useful.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Absolutely. It was very detailed, and that's exactly what we're looking for. So, just to kick things off, could you tell me a little more about what originally led you to choose the COWIN E7s specifically? You mentioned budget and needing something for your commute.

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Right, yeah. So, my old earbuds, they were just some cheap wired ones, started crapping out. And I was getting tired of the constant noise on the bus every day, you know? It's pretty loud, people talking, the engine hum, all that. I wanted something *over-ear* because I figured they'd be more comfortable and block more sound passively, and *Bluetooth* was a must. I didn't want to deal with tangled wires anymore, especially when I'm trying to get stuff out of my backpack.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: That makes perfect sense. So, over-ear, Bluetooth, and you were specifically looking for some form of noise cancellation?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, absolutely. That was, like, a top priority. I saw the E7s advertised with Active Noise Cancelling, and the price point was, honestly, pretty appealing. I mean, I'm 18, so I'm not rolling in cash, but I do work a sales job, so I have some disposable income. But I still need to be smart with it. I checked out some reviews online, and a lot of them said they were a "good value" for the price. So I thought, okay, let's give these a shot.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Okay, so a clear need for noise cancellation, wireless, and over-ear, all within a specific budget. Did you look at any other brands or models before settling on the E7s, or were these just the ones that really caught your eye?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Um, I mean, I looked at a few. Mostly online, you know, Amazon, Best Buy. I saw some Sony ones, some Bose, but those were way out of my price range. Like, hundreds of dollars. I was probably looking for something, I don't know, under a hundred, maybe closer to sixty or seventy bucks. I just needed something functional, not high-end audiophile stuff. The COWINs just hit that sweet spot of features for the price.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Got it. So, a significant step up from your previous wired earbuds, aiming for a much better experience. You mentioned your daily commute on a moderately busy public bus. How frequently are you using these headphones, and is the bus commute the primary place you use them?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, pretty much every weekday. I'm on the bus for about 30-40 minutes each way, so an hour, hour and a half total, just commuting to work. And then, sometimes, I'll use them at home if I'm trying to focus on something, or just chilling and listening to music. But yeah, the bus is where they get their main workout.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Okay, so quite a bit of use, especially in that specific environment. Let's dive into the active noise cancellation, since that was a major draw for you. You said it was "barely acceptable" and "far from impressive." Could you elaborate a bit on what specific sounds it *did* manage to dull, and more importantly, what it *failed* to block out that you were hoping it would?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Sure. So, on the bus, the constant low hum of the engine? It definitely helps with that. It's like, uh, it knocks it down a few notches. And some of the general road noise, that lower rumble, it does take the edge off. So, it's not like I don't notice *any* difference when I turn it on. It's better than nothing, definitely.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: And what about the sounds that cut through? You mentioned conversations, announcements...

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, *those* are the problem. I mean, people talking near me, especially if they're loud or like, laughing, I can still hear them pretty clearly. And when the driver makes an announcement over the speaker, or if someone's phone rings loudly, or like, if there's a sudden brake or a car horn outside – those sharp, high-pitched noises, they just blast right through the noise canceling. It doesn't seem to touch them at all. It's not the immersive silence I pictured, you know? It's more like a thin filter, not a proper barrier. And then there's that faint hiss...

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Ah, yes, the hiss. You mentioned it becomes more prominent when music isn't playing. Is that a constant sound when ANC is on, or does it fluctuate?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: It's pretty constant, yeah. Like, if I'm just sitting there with ANC on and no music, or if a song ends, I can definitely hear it. It's not super loud, but it's there, and it's kinda annoying. Especially if I'm trying to, I don't know, just have some quiet time, or if I'm listening to a podcast with quiet parts. It just adds this layer of white noise that doesn't feel right.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: That's valuable feedback. So, it helps with the low-frequency hums but struggles with higher-frequency and sudden noises, and introduces its own hiss. Given that the ANC was a primary motivation, how much does this impact your overall satisfaction with the headphones for their intended purpose on your commute?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Oh, it impacts it a lot. I mean, if the ANC was better, I'd probably be a lot happier. It was probably the *main* reason I bought them. It still makes the commute *bearable* in some ways, because of the low hum reduction, but it's not what I was hoping for. It's like... it does *half* the job, maybe.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Understood. Let's shift gears a bit to sound quality. You described it as "bass-heavy, boomy, muddy," and said vocals sounded "indistinct." Could you give me an example of the type of music or audio you listen to where this becomes most apparent?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Uh, yeah, definitely. I listen to a lot of hip-hop, R&B, some pop, so I like bass, you know? But this is different. It's not a *clean* bass. It's just... thick. Like, it just kinda hangs around and muddies everything else up. When I listen to songs with prominent vocals, especially, like, female vocals or anything with a lot of harmonies, it feels like they're pushed back, almost like they're singing behind a curtain. The bass just bleeds into the mids, and everything gets jumbled. There's no separation.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: So, even for genres that typically favor bass, you found it to be poorly implemented. And you mentioned a lack of "clarity or separation." Is that something you'd notice more with certain instruments, or just generally across all types of audio?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Just generally. Like, if there are multiple instruments playing, or different layers in a song, it just blends into one big, kinda dull sound. Like I said in the review, the treble is recessed, too. So, no sparkle, no crispness to cymbals or high hats. Everything just sounds… flat, I guess. Lifeless.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: That's a very clear description. So, essentially, it detracts from the listening experience even for background music, despite the bass-heavy profile.

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, for sure. If I'm just listening to a podcast, it's fine. Voices are clear enough, even if they're a bit muffled. But for music? Nah. I usually end up switching to my phone speaker if I'm at home, which, you know, isn't ideal for privacy, but sometimes it just sounds better.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Wow, that's significant if you'd rather use a phone speaker. Let's move on to comfort, as that's crucial for extended wear. You noted warmth after an hour and discomfort from clamping force after 90 minutes. Can you describe what that discomfort feels like specifically? Is it pressure on your ears, temples, or something else?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: It's mostly pressure, yeah. On my ears, like the top part of my ear, and then my temples. It's not immediate, but after, like, an hour and a half, I start to feel it. It just feels like it's squeezing my head a bit too tight. And then with the warmth, especially now that it's starting to get warmer in Dallas, my ears just get sweaty. It's not pleasant. So yeah, I usually have to take them off and give my ears a break, even if I'm still on the bus.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: So, a combination of pressure and heat. And you also mentioned they're quite bulky and don't fold. How does that impact your daily routine or portability?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Oh, it's a pain. I usually just toss my headphones into my backpack with my books and stuff, but these are huge. And since they don't fold, they take up a ton of space. I'm always worried I'm going to break them when I'm cramming other stuff in. If they folded, or came with some sort of decent case, that would be way better for just carrying them around.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: I understand. That certainly limits their convenience for someone on the go. Now, on the positive side, you mentioned Bluetooth connectivity is stable and battery life is quite good. Could you tell me a bit more about what you like about those aspects?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, those are probably the best parts, honestly. I never really have connection drops, which is great. It pairs quickly, stays connected to my phone, no issues there. And the battery life is actually really solid. Like, I can go several days, probably four or five days of commuting, without having to charge them. That's a huge plus because I always forget to charge stuff, so it's one less thing to worry about.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: So, those two features are definitely meeting and maybe even exceeding your expectations. That's good to hear. What about the controls on the earcup? You said they were functional but "could be more intuitive." What makes them less intuitive for you?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Um, well, there are a few buttons, right? And they're all kinda similar shapes and in a row. So, when I'm wearing them, and I go to, like, skip a track or change the volume, I have to kinda feel around for the right one. I've accidentally hit the power button instead of volume up sometimes, or turned ANC off when I wanted to pause. It's not a huge deal, but it's just not as quick and easy as it should be. Sometimes I just pull out my phone instead, which kinda defeats the purpose of having controls on the headphones.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: I can see how that would be frustrating. And finally, on the call quality, you mentioned callers often say you sound distant or muffled. How often do you try to use them for calls, and how does that impact your decision to use them in general?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: I almost never use them for important calls now. If it's just a quick call to a friend, maybe. But if I'm calling my boss or someone for work, I'll definitely take them off and just use my phone. It's just not reliable. People always say, "What? Can't hear you!" And I have to switch. So, it's basically a listening-only device for me.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: That's a clear limitation. Benjamin, thinking beyond your commute, are there any other scenarios where you've tried to use the E7s, maybe for gaming, watching movies, or studying? And how did they perform in those situations?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Uh, not really for gaming, no. My PC setup has its own headphones. But for watching movies on my laptop, sometimes. The sound quality issues are still there, so movies with a lot of dialogue can be tricky because of the muddy mids. For studying, if I'm just playing instrumental background music, it's okay, but the ANC hiss can be distracting if it's too quiet. So, it's really mostly for the bus.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Okay, so their utility is quite focused due to these performance issues. You ended your review with "you get what you pay for" and called them a "temporary stop-gap." Could you expand on that price-value perception? What would make them feel like a *good* value for the price you paid, or what features would you be willing to pay more for to get a better experience?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Yeah, I mean, for seventy bucks or whatever I paid, I guess I shouldn't expect miracles. But I did expect the main features, like ANC and decent sound, to be, you know, *good*. Not just "barely there." If the ANC actually blocked out conversations and announcements, and if the sound was just, like, *balanced* and clear, not just boomy, I'd probably feel like I got a really good deal. I'd even pay, like, another thirty or forty bucks – maybe up to $100-$110 – if those things were fixed. For that price, I'd expect better sound and ANC.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: So, if they truly delivered on those core promises, even at a slightly higher price point, you'd feel the value proposition was much stronger. That's really helpful. If you were talking to a friend who was in a similar situation as you – needing affordable, over-ear Bluetooth with some noise cancellation for a commute – would you recommend the COWIN E7s to them? And why or why not?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Hmm, that's a tough one. I mean, if they were *exactly* like me, super tight budget, and literally just needed *anything* better than nothing for a bus commute, maybe. But I'd have to give them a huge disclaimer. Like, "Hey, these are gonna be okay, but don't expect much from the noise canceling, and the sound is kinda muddy, and they're not super comfy for long periods." So, not a strong recommendation, you know? More like, "Here's what I got, it *sorta* works, but save up if you can."

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: So, a very conditional recommendation, highlighting the compromises upfront. If you could suggest one or two specific improvements to the product team for a future version of the E7, what would be your top priorities?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Definitely the ANC. Make it actually block out higher frequencies and lose the hiss. That's number one for me. And then, the sound quality. Just make it more balanced. Less booming bass, clearer vocals. If you guys could nail those two, it would be a completely different product, for the better. And, uh, maybe make them fold, that'd be nice too.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Understood. Stronger, broader ANC and a more balanced sound profile are key. And increased portability. What, if anything, would make you consider switching to a competitor's product in the future, given your current experience?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Oh, for sure. If I found something that offered genuinely good ANC and decent sound, even if it cost a bit more, I'd probably jump on it. Especially if it was comfortable and didn't make my ears sweat. I mean, I bought these because of the price point, but I'm realizing now that sacrificing *that much* quality might not be worth the savings in the long run. I'd definitely be looking for better value, even if that means spending an extra fifty or seventy-five bucks next time.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Benjamin, this has been incredibly insightful. Your detailed feedback is exactly what we need to improve our products. Just one final question to wrap things up: on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, how would you rate your overall satisfaction with the COWIN E7 headphones today, considering everything we've discussed?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: Um, honestly? I'd probably stick with a 4. Maybe a 4.5. The battery and Bluetooth are good, but the core features I bought them for, the ANC and sound, they just don't deliver enough to make me really happy. It's a stop-gap, like I said.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: Thank you for that honest assessment, Benjamin. That 4-4.5 rating, along with all your specific points, gives us a lot to work with. We really appreciate your time and willingness to share your experience with us. Is there anything else you'd like to add before we conclude?

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: No, I think I covered everything. Thanks for listening, Mike.

transcript.speaker: Mike
transcript.text: My pleasure, Benjamin. We genuinely appreciate it. Have a great rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: Benjamin
transcript.text: You too.
